query: What is the difference between Redis Sorted Sets and regular Sets?
answer:
Based on the Redis documentation, here are the key differences between **Redis Sorted Sets** and **regular Sets**:

## Order

| Feature | Regular Sets | Sorted Sets |
|---------|--------------|-------------|
| **Ordering** | Unordered - elements returned in no particular order | Ordered by score, then lexicographically for ties |
| **Data structure** | Hash table | Skip list + hash table (dual-ported) |

## Key Characteristics

### Regular Sets (`SET`)
- **Unordered collection** of unique strings (members)
- No guarantee on the order of elements
- Support **set operations**: intersection (`SINTER`), union (`SUNION`), difference (`SDIFF`)
- Example use cases:
  - Tracking unique items (e.g., unique IP addresses)
  - Representing relations (e.g., users with a specific role)
  - Performing set operations

### Sorted Sets (`ZSET`)
- **Ordered collection** of unique strings paired with a **floating-point score**
- Elements are *already sorted* - no additional work needed when retrieving
- Ordered by score (ascending by default), with lexicographic ordering for same scores
- Example use cases:
  - Leaderboards (e.g., game high scores)
  - Rate limiters (sliding-window)
  - Time-series data

## Performance

- **Sets**: O(1) for add/remove/check membership
- **Sorted Sets**: O(log(N)) for add operations (due to skip list), but retrieval is already sorted

## Example

```redis
# Regular Set - order is random
> SADD bikes bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
> SMEMBERS bikes
1) bike:3
2) bike:1
3) bike:2  # Order not guaranteed

# Sorted Set - ordered by score
> ZADD leaderboard 100 "Alice" 200 "Bob" 50 "Charlie"
> ZRANGE leaderboard 0 -1
1) "Charlie"  # score 50
2) "Alice"    # score 100
3) "Bob"      # score 200
```

**Sources:**
- [Redis sorted sets](file:///Users/user/repos/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sorted-sets.md)
- [Redis sets](file:///Users/user/repos/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sets.md)

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='call_function_l3tew46q3yhg_1', content='{"result":"[\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 4.336,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"7aa61062\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7aa61062-000\\",\\n \\"chunk_index\\": 0,\\n \\"path\\": \\"../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sorted-sets.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Redis sorted sets\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"A Redis sorted set is a collection of unique strings (members) ordered by an associated score.\\\\nWhen more than one string has the same score, the strings are ordered lexicographically.\\\\nSome use cases for sorted sets include:\\\\n\\\\n* Leaderboards. For example, you can use sorted sets to easily maintain ordered lists of the highest scores in a massive online game.\\\\n* Rate limiters. In particular, you can use a sorted set to build a sliding-window rate limiter to prevent excessive API requests.\\\\n\\\\nYou can think of sorted sets as a mix between a Set and\\\\na Hash. Like sets, sorted sets are composed of unique, non-repeating\\\\nstring elements, so in some sense a sorted set is a set as well.\\\\n\\\\nHowever while elements inside sets are not ordered, every element in\\\\na sorted set is associated with a floating point value, called *the score*\\\\n(this is why the type is also similar to a hash, since every element\\\\nis mapped to a value).\\\\n\\\\nMoreover, elements in a sorted set are *taken in order* (so they are not\\\\nordered on request, order is a peculiarity of the data structure used to\\\\nrepresent sorted sets). They are ordered according to the following rule:\\\\n\\\\n* If B and A are two elements with a different score, then A > B if A.score is > B.score.\\\\n* If B and A have exactly the same score, then A > B if the A string is lexicographically greater than the B string. B and A strings can\'t be equal since sorted sets only have unique elements.\\\\n\\\\nLet\'s start with a simple example, we\'ll add all our racers and the score they got in the first race:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZADD racer_scores 10 \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> ZADD racer_scores 12 \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> ZADD racer_scores 8 \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\" 10 \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\" 6 \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\" 14 \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 4\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAs you can see [`ZADD`]() is similar to [`SADD`](), but takes one additional argument\\\\n(placed before the element to be added) which is the score.\\\\n[`ZADD`]() is also variadic, so you are free to specify multiple score-value\\\\npairs, as shown in the example above.\\\\n\\\\nWith sorted sets it is trivial to return a list of racers sorted by their\\\\nscore because actually *they are already sorted*.\\\\n\\\\nImplementation note: Sorted sets are implemented via a\\\\ndual-ported data structure containing both a skip list and a hash table, so\\\\nevery time we add an element Redis performs an O(log(N)) operation. That\'s\\\\ngood, so when we ask for sorted elements, Redis does not have to do any work at\\\\nall, it\'s already sorted. Note that the [`ZRANGE`]() order is low to high, while the [`ZREVRANGE`]() order is high to low:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZRANGE racer_scores 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n4) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n5) \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n6) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n> ZREVRANGE racer_scores 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n4) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n5) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n6) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nNote: 0 and -1 means from element index 0 to the last element (-1 works\\\\nhere just as it does in the case of the [`LRANGE`]() command).\\\\n\\\\nIt is possible to return scores as well, using the `WITHSCORES` argument:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZRANGE racer_scores 0 -1 withscores\\\\n 1) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n 2) \\\\\\"6\\\\\\"\\\\n 3) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n 4) \\\\\\"8\\\\\\"\\\\n 5) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n 6) \\\\\\"10\\\\\\"\\\\n 7) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n 8) \\\\\\"10\\\\\\"\\\\n 9) \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n10) \\\\\\"12\\\\\\"\\\\n11) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n12) \\\\\\"14\\\\\\"\\",\\n \\"agent_hint\\": \\"[overview | gaps:incomplete_steps,missing_example]\\",\\n \\"evidence_flags\\": {\\n \\"has_command\\": false,\\n \\"has_config\\": true,\\n \\"has_code_block\\": false,\\n \\"has_steps\\": false\\n }\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 1.3277,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"2e535593\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"2e535593-000\\",\\n \\"chunk_index\\": 0,\\n \\"path\\": \\"../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sets.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Redis sets\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"A Redis set is an unordered collection of unique strings (members).\\\\nYou can use Redis sets to efficiently:\\\\n\\\\n* Track unique items (e.g., track all unique IP addresses accessing a given blog post).\\\\n* Represent relations (e.g., the set of all users with a given role).\\\\n* Perform common set operations such as intersection, unions, and differences.\\\\n\\\\n* [`SADD`]() adds a new member to a set.\\\\n* [`SREM`]() removes the specified member from the set.\\\\n* [`SISMEMBER`]() tests a string for set membership.\\\\n* [`SINTER`]() returns the set of members that two or more sets have in common (i.e., the intersection).\\\\n* [`SCARD`]() returns the size (a.k.a. cardinality) of a set.\\\\n\\\\nSee the [complete list of set commands](?group=set).\\\\n\\\\n* Store the sets of bikes racing in France and the USA. Note that\\\\nif you add a member that already exists, it will be ignored.\\\\n\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:usa bike:1 bike:4\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Check whether bike:1 or bike:2 are racing in the US.\\\\n\\\\n> SISMEMBER bikes:racing:usa bike:1\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SISMEMBER bikes:racing:usa bike:2\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Which bikes are competing in both races?\\\\n\\\\n> SINTER bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* How many bikes are racing in France?\\\\n\\\\n> SCARD bikes:racing:france\\\\n(integer) 3\\",\\n \\"agent_hint\\": \\"[overview]\\",\\n \\"evidence_flags\\": {\\n \\"has_command\\": false,\\n \\"has_config\\": false,\\n \\"has_code_block\\": false,\\n \\"has_steps\\": false\\n }\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": -7.4799,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"7f44ec96\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7f44ec96-051\\",\\n \\"chunk_index\\": 51,\\n \\"path\\": \\"../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/modules/modules-api-ref.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Modules API reference\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Key API for Sorted Set iterator\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"\\",\\n \\"agent_hint\\": \\"[reference | gaps:missing_example]\\",\\n \\"evidence_flags\\": {\\n \\"has_command\\": false,\\n \\"has_config\\": true,\\n \\"has_code_block\\": true,\\n \\"has_steps\\": false\\n }\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 1.3224,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"7aa61062\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7aa61062-001\\",\\n \\"chunk_index\\": 1,\\n \\"path\\": \\"../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sorted-sets.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Redis sorted sets\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Operating on ranges\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"Sorted sets are more powerful than this. They can operate on ranges.\\\\nLet\'s get all the racers with 10 or fewer points. We\\\\nuse the [`ZRANGEBYSCORE`]() command to do it:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZRANGEBYSCORE racer_scores -inf 10\\\\n1) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n4) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nWe asked Redis to return all the elements with a score between negative\\\\ninfinity and 10 (both extremes are included).\\\\n\\\\nTo remove an element we\'d simply call [`ZREM`]() with the racer\'s name.\\\\nIt\'s also possible to remove ranges of elements. Let\'s remove racer Castilla along with all\\\\nthe racers with strictly fewer than 10 points:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZREM racer_scores \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> ZREMRANGEBYSCORE racer_scores -inf 9\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n> ZRANGE racer_scores 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n[`ZREMRANGEBYSCORE`]() is perhaps not the best command name,\\\\nbut it can be very useful, and returns the number of removed elements.\\\\n\\\\nAnother extremely useful operation defined for sorted set elements\\\\nis the get-rank operation. It is possible to ask what is the\\\\nposition of an element in the set of ordered elements.\\\\nThe [`ZREVRANK`]() command is also available in order to get the rank, considering\\\\nthe elements sorted in a descending way.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZRANK racer_scores \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> ZREVRANK racer_scores \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 2\\",\\n \\"agent_hint\\": \\"[overview | gaps:incomplete_steps,missing_example]\\",\\n \\"evidence_flags\\": {\\n \\"has_command\\": false,\\n \\"has_config\\": true,\\n \\"has_code_block\\": false,\\n \\"has_steps\\": false\\n }\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 0.2194,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"2e535593\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"2e535593-001\\",\\n \\"chunk_index\\": 1,\\n \\"path\\": \\"../my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sets.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Redis sets\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Limits\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"The [`SADD`]() command adds new elements to a set. It\'s also possible\\\\nto do a number of other operations against sets like testing if a given element\\\\nalready exists, performing the intersection, union or difference between\\\\nmultiple sets, and so forth.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:racing:france\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1 bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(integer) 3\\\\n> SMEMBERS bikes:racing:france\\\\n1) bike:3\\\\n2) bike:1\\\\n3) bike:2\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nHere I\'ve added three elements to my set and told Redis to return all the\\\\nelements. There is no order guarantee with a set. Redis is free to return the\\\\nelements in any order at every call.\\\\n\\\\nRedis has commands to test for set membership. These commands can be used on single as well as multiple items:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> SISMEMBER bikes:racing:france bike:1\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SMISMEMBER bikes:racing:france bike:2 bike:3 bike:4\\\\n1) (integer) 1\\\\n2) (integer) 1\\\\n3) (integer) 0\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nWe can also find the difference between two sets. For instance, we may want\\\\nto know which bikes are racing in France but not in the USA:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:usa bike:1 bike:4\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n> SDIFF bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThere are other non trivial operations that are still easy to implement\\\\nusing the right Redis commands. For instance we may want a list of all the\\\\nbikes racing in France, the USA, and some other races. We can do this using\\\\nthe [`SINTER`]() command, which performs the intersection between different\\\\nsets. In addition to intersection you can also perform\\\\nunions, difference, and more. For example \\\\nif we add a third race we can see some of these commands in action:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa bikes:racing:italy\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1 bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(integer) 3\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:usa bike:1 bike:4\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:italy bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4\\\\n(integer) 4\\\\n> SINTER bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa bikes:racing:italy\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n> SUNION bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa bikes:racing:italy\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n4) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n> SDIFF bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa bikes:racing:italy\\\\n(empty array)\\\\n> SDIFF bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n> SDIFF bikes:racing:usa bikes:racing:france\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nYou\'ll note that the [`SDIFF`]() command returns an empty array when the\\\\ndifference between all sets is empty. You\'ll also note that the order of sets\\\\npassed to [`SDIFF`]() matters, since the difference is not commutative.\\\\n\\\\nWhen you want to remove items from a set, you can use the [`SREM`]() command to\\\\nremove one or more items from a set, or you can use the [`SPOP`]() command to\\\\nremove a random item from a set. You can also _return_ a random item from a\\\\nset without removing it using the [`SRANDMEMBER`]() command:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:racing:france\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> SREM bikes:racing:france bike:1\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SPOP bikes:racing:france\\\\n\\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n> SMEMBERS bikes:racing:france\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:5\\\\\\"\\\\n> SRANDMEMBER bikes:racing:france\\\\n\\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\nThe max size of a Redis set is 2^32 - 1 (4,294,967,295) members.\\",\\n \\"agent_hint\\": \\"[overview]\\",\\n \\"evidence_flags\\": {\\n \\"has_command\\": false,\\n \\"has_config\\": false,\\n \\"has_code_block\\": false,\\n \\"has_steps\\": false\\n }\\n }\\n]\\n\\n[SEARCH NOTE] 以上为文档片段（chunks），可能不完整。如果 chunk 内容不足以完整回答问题（缺少具体步骤、命令、配置、代码），请用 Read(path) 读取对应文件获取完整上下文，严禁用通用知识补充。"}', is_error=None)]

1. **Sorted Sets** (from sorted-sets.md):
- Collection of unique strings ordered by an associated score
- If elements have the same score, they're ordered lexicographically
- Elements are stored in order (not ordered on request)
- Use cases: leaderboards, rate limiters, sliding-window rate limiters

2. **Sets** (from sets.md):
- Unordered collection of unique strings

[TextBlock(text='Based on the Redis documentation, here are the key differences between **Redis Sorted Sets** and **regular Sets**:

## Order

| Feature | Regular Sets | Sorted Sets |
|---------|--------------|-------------|
| **Ordering** | Unordered - elements returned in no particular order | Ordered by score, then lexicographically for ties |
| **Data structure** | Hash table | Skip list + hash table (dual-ported) |

## Key Characteristics

### Regular Sets (`SET`)
- **Unordered collection** of unique strings (members)
- No guarantee on the order of elements
- Support **set operations**: intersection (`SINTER`), union (`SUNION`), difference (`SDIFF`)
- Example use cases:
  - Tracking unique items (e.g., unique IP addresses)
  - Representing relations (e.g., users with a specific role)
  - Performing set operations

### Sorted Sets (`ZSET`)
- **Ordered collection** of unique strings paired with a **floating-point score**
- Elements are *already sorted* - no additional work needed when retrieving
- Ordered by score (ascending by default), with lexicographic ordering for same scores
- Example use cases:
  - Leaderboards (e.g., game high scores)
  - Rate limiters (sliding-window)
  - Time-series data

## Performance

- **Sets**: O(1) for add/remove/check membership
- **Sorted Sets**: O(log(N)) for add operations (due to skip list), but retrieval is already sorted

## Example

```redis
# Regular Set - order is random
> SADD bikes bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
> SMEMBERS bikes
1) bike:3
2) bike:1
3) bike:2  # Order not guaranteed

# Sorted Set - ordered by score
> ZADD leaderboard 100 "Alice" 200 "Bob" 50 "Charlie"
> ZRANGE leaderboard 0 -1
1) "Charlie"  # score 50
2) "Alice"    # score 100
3) "Bob"      # score 200
```

messages.result:
Based on the Redis documentation, here are the key differences between **Redis Sorted Sets** and **regular Sets**:

## Order

| Feature | Regular Sets | Sorted Sets |
|---------|--------------|-------------|
| **Ordering** | Unordered - elements returned in no particular order | Ordered by score, then lexicographically for ties |
| **Data structure** | Hash table | Skip list + hash table (dual-ported) |

## Key Characteristics

### Regular Sets (`SET`)
- **Unordered collection** of unique strings (members)
- No guarantee on the order of elements
- Support **set operations**: intersection (`SINTER`), union (`SUNION`), difference (`SDIFF`)
- Example use cases:
  - Tracking unique items (e.g., unique IP addresses)
  - Representing relations (e.g., users with a specific role)
  - Performing set operations

### Sorted Sets (`ZSET`)
- **Ordered collection** of unique strings paired with a **floating-point score**
- Elements are *already sorted* - no additional work needed when retrieving
- Ordered by score (ascending by default), with lexicographic ordering for same scores
- Example use cases:
  - Leaderboards (e.g., game high scores)
  - Rate limiters (sliding-window)
  - Time-series data

## Performance

- **Sets**: O(1) for add/remove/check membership
- **Sorted Sets**: O(log(N)) for add operations (due to skip list), but retrieval is already sorted

## Example

```redis
# Regular Set - order is random
> SADD bikes bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
> SMEMBERS bikes
1) bike:3
2) bike:1
3) bike:2  # Order not guaranteed

# Sorted Set - ordered by score
> ZADD leaderboard 100 "Alice" 200 "Bob" 50 "Charlie"
> ZRANGE leaderboard 0 -1
1) "Charlie"  # score 50
2) "Alice"    # score 100
3) "Bob"      # score 200
```
